factoid: The dining room in the house was exceedingly lofty.
The members of the household and the footmen stood waiting for Prince Andrew to enter.
Each footman stood behind a chair.
The head butler had a napkin on his arm.
The head butler scanned the setting of the table.
The head butler made signs to the footmen.
The head butler anxiously glanced from the clock to the door by which Prince Andrew was to enter.
Prince Andrew looked at a large gilt frame that was new to him.
The gilt frame contained the genealogical tree of the Princes Bolkónski.
Opposite the gilt frame hung another frame with a badly painted portrait.
The portrait was evidently painted by the estate's artist.
The portrait depicted a ruling prince wearing a crown.
The portrait prince was an alleged descendant of Rúrik.
The portrait prince was an ancestor of the Bolkónskis.
Prince Andrew looked again at the genealogical tree.
Prince Andrew shook his head laughing.
Prince Andrew laughed as a man laughs who looks at a portrait so characteristic of the original as to be amusing.
Prince Andrew said to Princess Mary, "How thoroughly like him that is!".
Princess Mary had come up to Prince Andrew.
Princess Mary looked at Prince Andrew in surprise.
Princess Mary did not understand what Prince Andrew was laughing at.
Everything Princess Mary's father did inspired her with reverence and was beyond question.
Prince Andrew continued, "Everyone has his Achilles’ heel."
Prince Andrew continued, "Fancy, with his powerful mind, indulging in such nonsense!"
Princess Mary could not understand the boldness of Prince Andrew’s criticism.
Princess Mary was about to reply when expected footsteps were heard coming from the study.
Prince Andrew walked in quickly and jauntily as was his wont.
Prince Andrew walked in as if intentionally contrasting the briskness of his manners with the strict formality of his house.
At that moment the great clock struck two.
Another shrill tone joined in from the drawing room.
Prince Andrew stood still.
Prince Andrew’s lively glittering eyes were under thick bushy eyebrows.
Prince Andrew sternly scanned all present.
Prince Andrew rested his gaze on the little princess.
The little princess felt the sensation of fear and respect when the Tsar entered.
The little princess felt the sensation of fear and respect because the old man inspired it in all around him.
Prince Andrew stroked the little princess’s hair.
Prince Andrew patted the little princess awkwardly on the back of her neck.
Prince Andrew said, "I’m glad, glad, to see you," looking attentively into the little princess’s eyes.
Prince Andrew quickly went to his place and sat down.
Prince Andrew said, "Sit down, sit down! Sit down, Michael Ivánovich!"
Prince Andrew indicated a place beside him to his daughter‑in‑law.
A footman moved the chair for the daughter‑in‑law.
The old man said, "Ho, ho!" casting his eyes on the little princess’s rounded figure.
The old man said, "You’ve been in a hurry. That’s bad!"
The old man laughed in his usual dry, cold, unpleasant way, with his lips only and not with his eyes.
The old man said, "You must walk, walk as much as possible, as much as possible."
The little princess did not wish to hear the old man’s words.
The little princess was silent and seemed confused.
Prince Andrew asked the little princess about her father.
The little princess began to smile and talk.
Prince Andrew asked about mutual acquaintances.
The little princess became more animated and chatted away giving greetings from various people and retelling town gossip.
The little princess said, "Countess Apráksina, poor thing, has lost her husband and she has cried her eyes out."
The little princess grew more lively.
As the little princess became animated, Prince Andrew looked at her more sternly.
Prince Andrew suddenly turned away and addressed Michael Ivánovich.

Prince Andrew said, "Well, Michael Ivánovich, our Bonaparte will be having a bad time of it. Prince Andrew has been telling me what forces are being collected against him! While you and I never thought much of him."
Michael Ivánovich did not know when "you and I" had said such things about Bonaparte.
Michael Ivánovich understood that he was wanted as a peg on which to hang Prince Andrew’s favorite topic.
Michael Ivánovich looked inquiringly at Prince Andrew, wondering what would follow.
Prince Andrew said, "He is a great tactician!" to his son, pointing to the architect.
